timeline: Approximately 2 weeks after Chapter 1, spanning one month
location: Sector 12, Building 7, Reed's apartment and common areas

knows: He has 500 million credits from corporate black ops fund
He's set up anonymous UBI payments for his building
He's using his old financial analyst skills
People are starting to believe the money is real
Reed Salazar.emotional_state: Numb curiosity overlaying grief and nihilism. High on Leveler. Describes it as 'either most interesting thing I've done or will get me killed. Possibly both.'
Reed Salazar.physical_state: Using Leveler regularly, hands shaking when not high, still malnourished

knows: He received 2000 credits from 'Future Forward Solutions'
The money appeared two months in a row
He bought his daughter new shoes
He doesn't know who's behind it
Marcus Ibrahim.emotional_state: Deeply suspicious but starting to hope. Terrified of the trap but desperate for relief.
Marcus Ibrahim.physical_state: Still in chronic pain, still missing fingers, but slightly less stressed

knows: They received the mysterious 2000 credits twice
Everyone in the building got it
Yuki Tanaka.emotional_state: Anxious and oscillating between hope and fear of the trap

knows: He quit his worst job (overnight cargo processing)
He slept eight hours for the first time in years
Chen Rodriguez.emotional_state: Terrified but exhilarated. 'Either best or worst decision of my life.'

revealed_to_reader: Reed has 500 million credits from corporate black ops fund (found in chapters 2-3)
He's set up anonymous UBI payments of 2000 credits/month for all 200 units in his building
The payments route through shell accounts and fake company 'Future Forward Solutions'
Reed has financial analyst skills from before he became a dealer
He has 125 months of funding (about 10 years)
People in Sector 12 are deeply suspicious of good things - assume everything is a scam
First person to quit a job: Chen Rodriguez, overnight shift
The community is starting to hope but scared to believe
Reed is doing this as a kind of experiment to prove his brother's death meant something

planted.significance: First domino - will inspire others to quit bad jobs
Community bonds that will strengthen throughout book and become mutual aid network
First sign of Marcus being able to provide for his kids, eventual arc of him finding new purpose
Word will spread beyond building, eventually reaching Dr. Osei
He won't make it 10 years - money will run out in Book 3 and he'll die before seeing full results

planted.element: People's assumption that 'corporate doesn't give you money'
planted.significance: This systemic distrust will be both obstacle and protection for Reed

active_tensions: Will the money keep coming or is it a scam?
Will people spend it or save it defensively?
Will corporate notice the irregular transfers?
What will happen when people start quitting jobs?
world_changes: 200 units in Building 7 now receiving 2000 credits/month
First resident (Chen) has quit a terrible job
Community starting to gather and discuss openly - unusual for Sector 12
Hope appearing in Sector 12 for first time
continuity_notes: Payments are 2000 credits per month per unit
Total funding available: 500 million credits = 125 months = ~10 years
Transfers happen on first of month at 6 AM
Source shows as 'Future Forward Solutions' (fake company Reed created)
Payments route through 17 different sector exchanges
Reed uses his old financial analyst skills to set up the system
Chen's worst job was overnight cargo processing in freezing temperatures

voice_check.Reed: Maintained - 'This was either the most interesting thing he'd ever done, or it would get him killed. Possibly both.' Deadpan, flat affect, ironic detachment
voice_check.Yuki: Established - 'talking too fast, always talking too fast', nervous, apologetic, anxious
voice_check.Marcus: Established - thoughtful, slow speech, cynical but not hopeless, 'In my experience' phrases
voice_check.Chen: New - slightly unhinged laughter when stressed, direct

themes_developed: What if people aren't lazy, just tired?
Systemic distrust as both survival mechanism and trap
The first domino: one person making a brave choice
Hope as dangerous in exploitative systems
